[[Chloride]]
[[Bromide]] }} }} An '''iodide''' [[ion]] is the ion I−.{{Greenwood&Earnshaw}} Compounds with [[iodine]] in formal [[oxidation state]] −1 are called '''iodides'''. This page is for the iodide ion and its salts, not [[organoiodine compound]]s. In everyday life, iodide is most commonly encountered as a component of [[iodized salt]], which many governments mandate. Worldwide, [[iodine deficiency]] affects two billion people and is the leading preventable cause of [[intellectual disability]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/16/health/16iodine.html?fta=y|title=In Raising the World’s I.Q., the Secret’s in the Salt|last=McNeil|first=Donald G. Jr|date=2006-12-16|work=New York Times|accessdate=2008-12-04}} ==Structure and characteristics of inorganic iodides== Iodide is one of the largest monatomic [[anion]]s. It is assigned a radius of around 206 [[picometer]]s. For comparison, the lighter halides are considerably smaller: [[bromide]] (196 pm), [[chloride]] (181 pm), and fluoride (133 pm). In part because of its size, iodide forms relatively weak bonds with most elements. Most iodide salts are soluble in water, but often less so than the related chlorides and bromides. Iodide, being large, is less hydrophilic compared to the smaller anions. One consequence of this is that sodium iodide is highly soluble in acetone, whereas sodium chloride is not. The low solubility of [[silver iodide]] and [[lead iodide]] reflects the covalent character of these metal iodides. A test for the presence of iodide ions is the formation of yellow precipitates of these compounds upon treatment of a solution of [[silver nitrate]] or [[lead(II) nitrate]]. Aqueous solutions of iodide salts dissolve iodine better than pure water. This effect is due to the formation of the [[triiodide]] ion, which is brown: :I− + I2 ⇌ {{chem|I|3|−}} ===Redox, including antioxidant properties=== Iodide salts are mild [[reducing agent]]s and many react with oxygen to give iodine. A reducing agent is a chemical term for an antioxidant. Its antioxidant properties can be expressed quantitatively as a [[redox potential]] : :I− ⇌ {{1/2}} I2 + [[Electron|e−]]{{spaces|5}} ''E''° = −0.54 volts (versus [[Standard hydrogen electrode|SHE]]) Because iodide is easily oxidized, some enzymes readily convert it into [[electrophilic]] iodinating agents, as required for the [[biosynthesis]] of myriad iodide-containing [[natural product]]s. Iodide can function as an antioxidant [[redox|reducing]] species that can destroy [[reactive oxygen species]] such as [[hydrogen peroxide]]:{{cite journal |author=Küpper FC |title=Iodide accumulation provides kelp with an inorganic antioxidant impacting atmospheric chemistry |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America |volume=105 |issue=19 |pages=6954–8 |year=2008|pmid=18458346 |pmc=2383960 |doi=10.1073/pnas.0709959105|format=Free full text |author2=Carpenter LJ|authorlink2=Lucy Carpenter |author3=McFiggans GB |display-authors=3 |last4=Palmer |first4=C. J. |last5=Waite |first5=T. J. |last6=Boneberg |first6=E.-M. |last7=Woitsch |first7=S. |last8=Weiller |first8=M. |last9=Abela |first9=R.|bibcode = 2008PNAS..105.6954K |url=http://bib-pubdb1.desy.de/record/85506/files/Kuepper%20et%20al%20Fig%203.pdf }} :2 I− + peroxidase + H2O2 + tyrosine, histidine, lipid, etc. → iodo-compounds + H2O + 2 e− (antioxidants). ==Representative iodides== {| class="wikitable" style = "text-align:center" |- !Compound !Formula !Appearance !Use or occurrence |- |[[Potassium iodide]] | KI | white crystals | iodine component of iodized salt |- |[[Hydrogen iodide]] | HI | colourless gas | strong mineral acid |- |[[Silver iodide]] | AgI | yellow powder that darkens in light | photoactive component of silver-based photographic film |- |[[Thyroxine]]
(3,5,3′,5′-tetraiodothyronine) | C15H11I4NO4 | pale yellow solid | hormone essential for human health |- |} {{iodides}} ==Natural occurrence== Iodargyrite - natural, crystalline silver iodide - is the most common iodide mineral currently known. Iodide anions may sometimes also be found combined with mercury, copper and lead, but minerals with such compositions are even more scarce.http://www.mindat.org ==Other oxyanions== [[Iodine]] can assume [[oxidation state]]s of −1, +1, +3, +5, or +7. A number of neutral [[iodine oxide]]s are also known. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Iodine oxidation state | −1 | +1 | +3 | +5 | +7 |- ! Name | '''iodide''' | [[hypoiodite]] | [[iodite]] | [[iodate]] | [[periodate]] |- ! Formula | I− | IO− | {{chem|IO|2|−}} | {{chem|IO|3|−}} | {{chem|IO|4|−}} or {{chem|IO|6|5−}} |} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{Cite web | title = Seaweed use iodine as an antioxidant | work = Chemistry World blog | accessdate = 2008-05-15 | url = http://prospect.rsc.org/blogs/cw/?p=956 }} *{{Cite web | title = Stressed seaweed contributes to cloudy coastal skies, study suggests | accessdate = 2008-05-15 | url = http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2008-05/uom-ssc050608.php }} {{iodine compounds}} [[Category:Iodides| ]] [[Category:Anions]] [[Category:Dietary minerals]] [[Category:Dietary antioxidants]] [[Category:Leaving groups]]

[[Blizzard]] |date formed = {{start date|2017|3|9}} |date dissipated = {{end date|2017|3|18}} |RSI = 10.66 |maximum amount = Snow – {{convert|58|in|cm}} in [[Bolton Valley]], [[Vermont]]{{cite web|url=https://weather.com/storms/winter/news/winter-storm-stella-northeast-blizzard-warning-noreaster-snow-forecast-march-2017|title=Winter Storm Stella a Record Snowstorm for Binghamton, New York; Over 30 Inches of Snow Reported From Northeast Bombogenesis|date=March 14, 2017|work=The Weather Channel}}
Ice – {{convert|0.40|in|mm}} in [[Chesilhurst, New Jersey]] |lowest pressure = 974 | fujitascale = EF1 | tornadoes = 3 on March 13 (all in [[Florida]]) | tornado duration = 4 hours, 3 minutes |enhanced = yes |sustained wind = |gust = {{convert|138|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} on [[Mount Washington (New Hampshire)|Mount Washington, New Hampshire]] |damages = | power outages = 100,000+ |areas affected = Southwestern [[Canada]], [[Great Plains]], [[Upper Midwest]], [[Ohio Valley]], [[Northeastern United States]] (particularly the [[Mid-Atlantic states]] and [[New England]]), [[British Isles]] |total fatalities = 16–19 fatalities |notes = Part of the '''[[2016–17 North American winter]]''' }} The '''March 2017 North American blizzard''' was a major late-season [[blizzard]] that affected the [[Northeastern United States]], [[New England]] and [[Canada]], dumping up to {{convert|3|ft|in cm}} of [[snow]] in the hardest hit areas, mainly [[New York (state)|New York]], [[Vermont]], [[New Hampshire]] and Southern [[Quebec]]. Forming out of an [[extratropical cyclone]] near the [[Northwestern United States|Northwest]], the storm system dived into the northern portions of the United States, dropping light to moderate snow across the [[Great Lakes]], [[Upper Midwest]] on March 11–12 before reaching the [[Ohio Valley]] the next day. It later coalesced into a powerful [[nor'easter]] off the East Coast, producing a swath of heavy snowfall across a large portion of the Northeast. The storm was given various unofficial names, such as ''Winter Storm Stella'', ''Blizzard Eugene'', and ''Blizzard of 2017''. Ahead of the storm, residents prepared in advance for the major nor'easter, with [[blizzard warning]]s issued for several states, including [[New York (state)|New York]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[New Jersey]], [[Connecticut]], [[Rhode Island]], and [[Massachusetts]]. Several officials had crews with salt trucks ready to deploy to clear roads. The system also disrupted travel across the country, with numerous flight cancellations at most of the major airports in the Northeast. It dropped a swath of moderate snow accumulation as it moved across the northern tier of the country, with as much as {{convert|13|in|cm}} reported. The storm was also responsible for ending a record streak without snowfall in [[Chicago, Illinois]], where no snow had occurred since December 25, 2016.{{cite web|url=https://weather.com/news/news/chicago-no-snow-january-february-2017|title=Winter Storm Stella Ends Chicago's Record-Long Stretch Without Snow Cover|work=weather.com|accessdate=13 March 2017}} == Meteorological history == [[File:WPC LPA Forecast Mar 13 2017 1958UTC.gif|thumb|left|Projected paths for the developing low off the East Coast. Issued 3 p.m. EST (20:00 UTC) on March 13.]] On March 9, an [[extratropical cyclone]] formed in the [[North Pacific Ocean]]. On March 11, it began to affect parts of the [[Northwestern United States]] as well as [[British Columbia]] in [[Canada]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=03/11/2017&selmap=2017031112&maptype=satsfcnps|title=WPC Surface Analysis for 12:00 UTC on 3/11/2017|work=[[Weather Prediction Center]]|date=March 11, 2017|accessdate=March 12, 2017}} It eventually moved ashore later that day and transferred its energy to a new surface low, which began to move southeastwards into the United States as an [[Alberta clipper]]. The system moved swiftly across the [[Upper Midwest]] throughout the day of March 12, dropping a swath of accumulating snow of {{convert|3–6|in|cm}} as [[frontogenesis]] took place.{{cite web|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=03/11/2017&selmap=2017031215&maptype=satsfcnps|title=WPC Surface Analysis for 15:00 UTC on 3/12/2017|work=[[Weather Prediction Center]]|date=March 12, 2017}} On March 13 at 15:00 UTC, the [[Weather Prediction Center]] began issuing storm summaries while the system was located west-northwest of [[St. Louis, Missouri]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/storm12/stormsum_1.html|title=Storm Summary Number 01 for Upper Midwest to Northeast Winter Storm|work=Weather Prediction Center|date=March 13, 2017}} Throughout the day, a weak secondary area of low pressure formed in the [[Gulf of Mexico]] and drifted northeastwards, while not expected to fuse with the other low to its north, it helped inject moisture from the ocean over the state of [[Florida]], which gradually began to merge with the outermost fringes of the northerly system that had now moved into the [[Ohio Valley]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=03/12/2017&selmap=2017031318&maptype=satsfcnps|title=WPC Surface Analysis for 15:00 UTC on 3/13/2017|work=[[Weather Prediction Center]]|date=March 13, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/storm12/stormsum_2.html|title=Storm Summary Number 02 for Upper Midwest to Northeast Winter Storm|work=Weather Prediction Center|date=March 13, 2017}} By 21:00 UTC that night, a new surface low developed off the [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] coastline with a central pressure of {{convert|1010|mbar|inHg}},{{cite web|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=03/12/2017&selmap=2017031321&maptype=satsfcnps|title=WPC Surface Analysis for 21:00 UTC on 3/13/2017|work=[[Weather Prediction Center]]|date=March 13, 2017}} eventually becoming the dominant low of the nor'easter. The storm began to [[explosive cyclogenesis|rapidly deepen]] as it moved parallel to the [[East Coast of the United States]], with the central pressure dropping to {{convert|986|mbar|inHg}} by 15:00 UTC on March 14 while it was just off the [[Maryland]] coastline.{{cite web|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/sfc/sfc_archive_maps.php?arcdate=03/12/2017&selmap=2017031415&maptype=satsfcnps|title=WPC Surface Analysis for 15:00 UTC on 3/14/2017|work=[[Weather Prediction Center]]|date=March 14, 2017}} The storm continued to intensify as it drifted northeastwards towards [[Long Island]], continuing to produce an expansive area of snow with heavier rates embedded in snowbands across [[Connecticut]], northern [[New York (state)|New York]] and most of interior [[New England]], as well as parts of [[Canada]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/storm12/stormsum_6.html|title=Storm Summary Number 06 for Upper Midwest to Northeast Winter Storm|work=Weather Prediction Center|date=March 14, 2017}} The low subsequently reached its peak intensity of {{convert|974|mbar|inHg}} while just inland over Long Island. By 20:00 UTC, most of the snow had come to an end in [[New Jersey]], [[Delaware]], and [[Washington D.C.]], as the low began to move inland over New England; subsequently it also began to weaken as it traveled further inland, and by early on March 15, snow began to end in more parts of the region.{{cite web|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/storm12/stormsum_8.html|title=Storm Summary Number 08 for Upper Midwest to Northeast Winter Storm|work=Weather Prediction Center|date=March 15, 2017}} The system continued to weaken as it moved slowly through upper [[New England]], the system continued to weaken, consequently, the Weather Prediction Center terminated storm summaries on the winter storm as nearly most of the moderate to heavy snow had stopped in the region and switched to rain. On March 18, the low that was formerly the blizzard had moved out to sea and dissipated. ===Forecasting controversy=== Predictions of the storm were criticized by some due to overestimation of the predicted snowfall totals in the major metropolitan areas including [[New York City]], with ''[[The Daily Mail]]'' calling it "the blizzard that WASN'T".{{cite web|url=https://weather.com/storms/winter/news/winter-storm-stella-northeast-bust-march-2017|title=Winter Storm Stella Wasn't Really a Forecast Bust – Except Along I-95|work=weather.com|accessdate=14 March 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-4311374/Storm-Stella-causes-states-emergency-claims-two-lives.html|title=Storm Stella causes states of emergency, claims two lives|work=dailymail.co.uk|accessdate=14 March 2017}} On March 14, New York Governor [[Andrew Cuomo]] stated that the storm was not as bad as previously anticipated, due to the change over to a mix of snow and [[Rain and snow mixed|sleet]], but advised residents to not let their guard down, as the storm was still predicted to cause high wind gusts and coastal flooding.{{Cite news|url=http://kwbe.com/abc_national/severe-winter-storm-bears-down-on-northeast-abcid35877771/|title=Severe winter storm bears down on Northeast|work=Beatrice News Channel|access-date=2017-03-14|language=en-US}} The reduction in snowfall totals was due to a shift in the storm's track to the west more towards the [[New Jersey]] coastline, which resulted in more mixed precipitation rather than snow. Initially, the [[National Weather Service]] predicted that the blizzard would leave New York City with up to {{convert|12–24|in|cm}} (rivaling it almost with the [[Great Blizzard of 1888]]), however these totals were later reduced due to the change in the system's track.{{Cite news|url=http://www.kansas.com/news/business/article138359753.html|title=The Latest: Tidal flooding in New Jersey as nor'easter hits|work=kansas|access-date=2017-03-14|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://live.nydailynews.com/Event/Tracking_the_2017_NYC_blizzard_updates_advisories_and_photos_from_the_March_snowstorm|title=Tracking the 2017 NYC blizzard: updates, advisories and photos from the March snowstorm|work=NY Daily News|access-date=2017-03-14|language=en}} Similarly, the metro area faced a similar situation [[January 2015 North American blizzard#Forecasting controversy|a little over two years prior]] where New York City was predicted to receive up to {{convert|2–3|ft|in}} of snow, but only received less than half of the predicted amount due to a shift in the storm's track by {{convert|50–100|mi|km}}. Meteorologists at the National Weather Service were aware of the changing conditions that led to lesser snow accumulations along the coast the night prior to the expected event. In a multi-office conference, however, forecasters decided to maintain the higher-than-likely snowfall predictions "out of extreme caution." They sought to avoid sending mixed and/or incorrect messages about a dangerous storm by maintaining a steady forecast.{{cite web|author=Seth Borenstein |publisher=Associated Press |date=March 14, 2017 |accessdate=March 14, 2017 |title=Weather Service decided last minute not to cut snow forecast |url=https://apnews.com/8e8516da51234851b2fa50ee71d6636a/Weather-Service-decided-last-minute-not-to-cut-snow-forecast |archivedate=March 15, 2017 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6oy7OqVjw?url=https://apnews.com/8e8516da51234851b2fa50ee71d6636a/Weather-Service-decided-last-minute-not-to-cut-snow-forecast |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==Preparations== {| class="wikitable" align="right" style="margin: 1em; margin-top: 0;" |+ align="center" | Weather alerts at 6:36 p.m. EST (23:36 UTC) on March 13 in advance of the winter storm around Pennsylvania and New Jersey | colspan="4" align="center" | [[File:Watches and warnings for winter storm NWS Mt Holly Mar 13 2017 2336 UTC.png|250px]] |- | style="width:10px; height:10px; background:#FF4500;" | ||  [[Blizzard warning]] | style="width:10px; height:5px; background:#FF69B4;" | ||  [[Winter storm warning]] |- | style="width:10px; height:10px; background:#9400D3;" | ||  [[Storm warning]] | style="width:10px; height:5px; background:#DDA0DD;" | ||  [[Gale warning]] |- | style="width:10px; height:5px; background:#D8BFD8;" | ||  [[Small craft advisory]] | style="width:10px; height:5px; background:#DAA520;" | ||  [[High wind warning]] |- | colspan="4" |{{Center|'''Weather alerts at 6:37 p.m. EST (23:37 UTC)''' '''on March 13 in advance of the winter storm around''' '''the Boston metro area.'''}} |- | colspan="4" |{{Center|[[File:Watches and warnings for winter storm NWS Box 13 2017 2337 UTC.png|frameless|250px]]}} |} [[Amtrak]] made several adjustments to service on the [[Northeast Corridor]] in preparation of the storm. On the ''[[Acela Express]]'', service was suspended between [[New York City]] and [[Boston]] and reduced between [[Washington, D.C.]] and New York City on March 14. ''[[Northeast Regional]]'' trains were placed on a modified schedule on March 14 with several trains shortened or cancelled. ''[[Keystone Service]]'' trains were placed on a severe weather schedule for March 14.{{cite news|title=Amtrak announces snowstorm service plan|publisher=WPVI-TV|location=Philadelphia, PA|date=March 13, 2017|url=http://6abc.com/weather/amtrak-announces-snowstorm-service-plan/1798565/|accessdate=March 14, 2017}} [[Bieber Transportation Group]] cancelled buses to [[Philadelphia]] and New York City on March 14.{{cite news|title=Bieber buses to, from Philadelphia, New York idled by storm|publisher=WFMZ-TV|location=Allentown, PA|date=March 14, 2017|url=http://www.wfmz.com/news/berks/bieber-buses-to-from-philadelphia-new-york-idled-by-storm/395068785|accessdate=March 14, 2017}} [[Donald Trump|President Donald Trump]] postponed a meeting with [[Angela Merkel]] due to the nor'easter.{{Cite news|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2017/mar/13/donald-trump-angela-merkel-postpone-meeting-due-sn/|title=Donald Trump, Angela Merkel postpone meeting due to snow forecast|last=http://www.washingtontimes.com|first=The Washington Times|work=The Washington Times|access-date=2017-03-14|language=en-US}} ===Mid-Atlantic (United States)=== On March 11, the [[National Weather Service]] issued [[blizzard watch]]es for parts of the Northeast, including [[New York City]].{{cite web|url=https://weather.com/storms/winter/news/winter-storm-stella-blizzard-noreaster-south-snow-forecast-march-2017|title=Blizzard Warnings Issued as Winter Storm Stella Gears Up to Deliver More Than a Foot of Snow to a Widespread Swath of the Northeast|work=[[The Weather Channel]]|accessdate=13 March 2017}} Late on March 12, officials issued a hazardous travel advisory in advance of the storm, which was predicted to bring up to {{convert|18|in|cm}} of snow to parts of the state, including [[Staten Island]].{{cite web|url=http://www.silive.com/news/index.ssf/2017/03/hazardous_travel_advisory_issu.html|title=Hazardous travel advisory issued in advance of winter storm 'Stella'|work=Silive.com|accessdate=13 March 2017}} The following day on March 13, New York City mayor [[Bill de Blasio]] urged the residents of the region to avoid traveling at any point due to the dangerous conditions and also allowing for sanitation crews to respond faster.{{cite web|url=https://weather.com/news/news/winter-storm-stella-new-york-impacts|title=Winter Storm Stella in New York, Tri-State: Mayor de Blasio Urges Residents to Avoid Travel Tuesday|work=The Weather Channel|accessdate=13 March 2017}} The [[New York City Department of Sanitation]] said that they had nearly 700 salt spreaders across the boroughs of the state, and 1,600 plows would be dispatched to clear the roadways. [[New York (state)|New York]] Governor [[Andrew Cuomo]] advised everyone in a statement that "[I] encourage all New Yorkers in affected regions to plan ahead, and avoid any unnecessary travel as the storm progresses," and also said to expect disruptions to travel and transportation. [[File:March 2017 nor'easter 2017-03-13 1745Z.png|thumb|The precursor to the blizzard developing over the [[Southeastern United States]] on March 13]] A state of emergency was declared in New York City on March 13, in which the [[New York City Subway|subway system]] will be shut down on March 14.{{Cite web|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2017/03/13/march-snow-storm-preparations/|title=De Blasio, Cuom Declare States Of Emergency; Above-Ground MTA Subways, Schools Shut Down For Snowstorm|last=Says|first=Auggey|access-date=2017-03-13}} The state also declared state of emergency.{{Cite news|url=https://www.northcountrypublicradio.org/news/story/33560/20170313/cuomo-declares-state-of-emergency-for-ny-as-nor-easter-advances|title=Cuomo declares state of emergency for NY as Nor'easter advances|work=NCPR|access-date=2017-03-13}} On March 13, a snow emergency was declared for [[Philadelphia]], which was to go into effect later that night.{{cite web|url=http://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2017/03/13/code-blues-snow-emergencies-issued-ahead-of-winter-storm/|title=Code Blues, Snow Emergencies Issued Ahead Of Winter Storm|work=cbslocal.com|accessdate=13 March 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://weather.com/storms/winter/news/philadelphia-pennsylvania-winter-storm-stella-preps-impacts|title=Snow Emergency Declared in Philly as Winter Storm Stella Looms|work=weather.com|accessdate=13 March 2017}} 50,000 tons of salt were said to be available and salting would begin when the snow arrived. [[Pennsylvania]] Governor [[Tom Wolf]] signed a proclamation of disaster that day and stated that speeds would be restricted on most major freeways.{{cite web|url=http://www.pennlive.com/news/2017/03/gov_wolfs_emergency_proclamati.html#incart_push|title=Gov. Wolf's emergency proclamation, travel restrictions: Here's what they entail|work=pennlive.com|accessdate=13 March 2017}} Several businesses and attractions in Philadelphia closed on March 14 including the [[Philadelphia Zoo]] and the [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]].{{cite news|title=Philadelphia Zoo, Art Museum among businesses closed Tuesday|publisher=WPVI-TV|location=Philadelphia, PA|date=March 13, 2017|url=http://6abc.com/weather/philadelphia-zoo-art-museum-among-businesses-closed-tuesday/1798668/|accessdate=March 13, 2017}} [[SEPTA]] made changes to bus and train service in anticipation of the storm, with service on several bus routes altered or suspended and [[SEPTA Regional Rail|Regional Rail]] service running on a modified Saturday schedule on March 14.{{cite news|title=SEPTA announces plan for snowstorm|publisher=WPVI-TV|location=Philadelphia, PA|date=March 13, 2017|url=http://6abc.com/weather/septa-announces-plan-for-snowstorm/1798503/|accessdate=March 13, 2017}} Several flights at [[Philadelphia International Airport]] on March 14 were cancelled in anticipation of the storm.{{cite news|title=Airlines begin to cancel flights at Philadelphia Int'l Airport ahead of storm|publisher=WPVI-TV|location=Philadelphia, PA|date=March 13, 2017|url=http://6abc.com/weather/airlines-begin-to-cancel-flights-at-phl-ahead-of-storm/1797947/|accessdate=March 13, 2017}} The [[Berks Area Regional Transportation Authority]] and [[Lehigh and Northampton Transportation Authority]] cancelled all service on March 14.{{cite news|title=LANTA, BARTA services canceled Tuesday|publisher=WFMZ-TV|location=Allentown, PA|date=March 14, 2017|url=http://www.wfmz.com/news/lehigh-valley/lanta-barta-services-canceled-tuesday/394676375|accessdate=March 14, 2017}} The [[United States Postal Service]] closed post offices and cancelled mail delivery for several locations in Pennsylvania on March 14.{{cite news|title=Winter storm forces postal service to suspend deliveries|publisher=WFMZ-TV|location=Allentown, PA|date=March 14, 2017|url=http://www.wfmz.com/news/lehigh-valley/winter-storm-forces-postal-service-to-suspend-deliveries/394883482|accessdate=March 14, 2017}} Schools in Northern [[New Jersey]] have announced closures for Tuesday.{{Cite 14.{{Cite news|url=http://www.fox5dc.com/weather/241444472-story|title=Late-season snowstorm hits DC area|last=Fox|work=WTTG|access-date=2017-03-14|language=en-US}} It left the state by the late-afternoon of March 14.{{Cite web|url=http://baltimore.cbslocal.com/2017/03/14/the-nor-easter-left-its-mark-on-carroll-county-md/|title=The Nor' Easter Left Its Mark On ==== Virginia ==== [[File:Snow falling in Hybla Valley, night of March 13,2017.jpg|thumb|Snow on the ground in [[Hybla Valley, Virginia|Hybla Valley]], [[Virginia]], the night of March 13.]]Snow started falling on the evening of March 13. It had turned into sleet by the mid-morning of March 14. It left the state by the morning of March 14.{{Cite news|url=http://www.richmond.com/weather/nor-easter-departs-from-va-but-cold-winds-will-continue/article_3268f359-a171-5ea9-98ed-6ef488e7cacb.html|title=Near-record cold for Richmond in the wake of the nor'easter|last=Boyer|first=John|work=Richmond Times-Dispatch|access-date=2017-03-15|language=en}} ==== Washington, D.C. ==== Snow started falling on the evening of March 13. By the start of the day of March 14, it had turned into a wintry mix, then to rain.{{Cite news|url=http://wtop.com/weather/2017/03/survival-guide-dc-area-braces-wallop-snow/slide/1/|title=Survival Guide: Area braces for wallop of snow, sleet {{!}} WTOP|date=2017-03-14|work=WTOP|access-date=2017-03-14|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=http://washington.cbslocal.com/2017/03/14/dc-area-storm-brings-rain-snow/|title=D.C.-Area Storm Brings More Rain Than Snow|access-date=2017-03-14}} It left the area by the afternoon of March 14. [[Washington Dulles International Airport|Washington Dulles airport's]] flights starting departing at the end of the day.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/03/14/thousands-of-flights-canceled-as-winter-storm-stella-barrels-down-northeast.html|title=Transit slowly resumes after thousands of canceled flights delayed 500,000 travelers amid storm|last=Wang|first=Christine|date=2017-03-14|website=CNBC|access-date=2017-03-15}} === Canada === [[File:Snow accumulations 2017-03-14-15.svg|thumb|Snow accumulations in Canada in centimètres.]] ==== Quebec and Ontario ==== The snow began hitting [[Ontario]] and Quebec on March 13 around noon.{{Cite news|url=http://montrealgazette.com/news/local-news/winter-storm-warning-heavy-snow-zero-visibility|title=Chaos on Quebec roads as winter storm blows in|date=2017-03-15|work=Montreal Gazette|access-date=2017-03-16|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.cp24.com/weather/winter-storm-hits-southern-ontario-messy-commute-expected-tuesday-1.3322212|title=Winter storm hits southern Ontario; messy commute expected Tuesday|last=Freeman|first=Codi Wilson and Joshua|work=CP24|access-date=2017-03-16|language=en-CA}} It rapidly intensified in the afternoon over portions of Southern Quebec and the [[Eastern Townships]] before becoming a powerful blizzard over [[Montreal]] and its [[South Shore (Montreal)|South Shore]], as heavy snow bands came from the South-East and did a wrap-around effect just on the South Shore of Montreal, where the snow fell at a rate of more than 7.5 cm/hr (3 in/hr) for more than 6 hours between 6PM and midnight.[https://www.meteomedia.com/nouvelles/articles/tempete-hivernale--le-quebec-sur-un-pied-dalerte/80271 More than 75 cm in Some Areas - Weather Network (french ''Météo Media'') '''(fr)'''] [[Environment Canada]] reported that a blizzard officially occurred in Montreal and Quebec City. The storm continued to track Northeast and affected [[Quebec City]] and Eastern Quebec where blizzard conditions were also occurring in the night. At the end of the blizzard, 18 cm (7 in) were recorded in [[Ottawa]], 40 cm (16 in) in Montreal, 35 cm (14 in) in Quebec City, 55 cm (22 in) in [[Sherbrooke, Quebec|Sherbrooke]], 70 cm (28 in) in [[Drummondville]], and more than 75 cm (30 in) in several locations such as [[Saint-Hubert, Quebec|Saint-Hubert]], [[Vaudreuil-Dorion, Quebec|Vaudreuil-Dorion]] and [[Saint-Jean-sur-Richelieu]]. Winds from the Northeast increased in the [[Saint Lawrence River]] between Montreal and Quebec City in the evening, producing the blizzard. Wind gusts reached 107 km/h (66 mph) at [[YUL|Montreal Pierre-Elliott Trudeau International Airport]], 113 km/h (70 mph) at [[YHU|Saint-Hubert Airport]] on the South Shore and 140 km/h (87 mph) at [[YQB|Quebec International Airport]]. Numerous road [[pileup]]s occurred, most notably on [[Ontario Highway 401]] near [[Mallorytown, Ontario|Mallorytown]], on [[Quebec Autoroute 20|Quebec highway 20]] near [[Saint-Zotique, Quebec|Saint-Zotique]] (which caused a major fire, destroying several semis and killing one of their drivers), on [[Quebec Autoroute 10|highway 10]] near [[Magog, Quebec|Magog]], on [[Quebec Autoroute 40|highway 40]] near [[Lavaltrie, Quebec|Lavaltrie]] and on Highway 20 near [[Sainte-Hélène-de-Bagot, Quebec|Sainte-Hélène de Bagot]]. Road closures included [[Quebec Autoroute 15|highway 15]] near the USA border, highway 10 near Magog, highway 20 in Saint-Zotique and [[Saint-Eugène, Quebec|Saint-Eugène]], and most notably on [[Quebec Autoroute 13|highway 13]] on Montreal Island, where several hundreds of cars and trucks were left trapped for more than 14 hours due to communication and logistic issues complicating the evacuation. In [[Quebec]], many areas were left without power for more than 24 hours. In [[Quebec city]], the [[Saint-Lawrence river]] stepped out of its riverbed, flooding both areas of Quebec City and [[Lévis]].{{cite news|date=March 15, 2017 |title=Le fleuve déborde dans la région de Québec|url=http://ici.radio-canada.ca/nouvelle/1022400/fleuve-saint-laurent-debordement-tempete-quebec |publisher=ICI Radio-Canada |language=French}} Five people were killed during the storm itself.{{cite news |last=Duchaine |first=Gabrielle |last2=Teisceira-Lessard |first2=Philippe |title=Tempête: cinq morts, perturbations majeures dans les transports|url=http://www.lapresse.ca/actualites/201703/15/01-5078854-tempete-cinq-morts-perturbations-majeures-dans-les-transports.php |date= March 15, 2017|work=La Presse |accessdate=March 17, 2017|language=French}} At least two more (both elderly males) were found dead in Montreal in parked cars over the following days, presumably killed by heart attacks while attempting to clear them out.{{cite news |last=Perron |first=Lousi-Samuel |title=Tempête: un autre homme trouvé mort dans une voiture à Montréal|url=http://www.lapresse.ca/actualites/justice-et-affaires-criminelles/faits-divers/201703/16/01-5079395-tempete-un-autre-homme-trouve-mort-dans-une-voiture-a-montreal.php |date=March 16, 2017 |work=La Presse |accessdate=March 17, 2017}} ==== Atlantic Canada ==== The storm started affected [[New Brunswick]] in the afternoon on March 14, with the other [[Atlantic Canada|Atlantic Canadian]] provinces being hit in the early evening.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/articles/nor-easter-hits-eastern-canada-snow-wind-blizzard-conditions/79269|title=Atlantic Canada buried Post|access-date=2017-03-14|last2=Samenow|first2=Jason|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}{{Cite Connecticut based [[WFSB]] dubbed the storm ''Blizzard Eugene''.{{cite web|url=http://www.wfsb.com/story/34725379/winter-storm-eugene-comes-Tuesday|title=Blizzard Eugene, in less than 24 hours!|publisher=www.wfsb.com|date=March 14, 2017|accessdate=March 14, 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://mic.com/articles/171000/winter-storm-stella-or-eugene-why-does-the-blizzard-have-two-names#.VkVBY29N2|title=Winter Storm Stella or Eugene: Why does the blizzard have two names?|publisher=[[Mic (media company)]]|author=Marie Solis|date=March 13, 2017|accessdate=March 14, 2017}} The [[National Weather Service]] has stated though that, unlike hurricanes, it does not name winter storms. The practice of winter storm naming remains controversial in the United States. == See also == {{portal|Canada|Disasters|United States|Weather}} * [[1993 Storm of the Century]] – struck around the same time, and just as heavy * [[Early February 2013 North American blizzard]] – had a very similar origin from the merger of two lows into one off the East Coast * [[January 2015 North American blizzard]] – similar storm that had origins from an Alberta clipper, and was criticized for less snowfall totals in [[New York City]] as well when forecasts predicted much more {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == {{Commons category|March 2017 nor'easter|March 2017 North American blizzard}} {{United States winter storms}} [[Category:2016–17 North American winter]] [[Category:2017 in Connecticut]] [[Category:2017 in Maryland]] [[Category:2017 in Massachusetts]] [[Category:2017 in New Jersey]] [[Category:2017 in New York (state)]] [[Category:2017 in Ontario]] [[Category:2017 in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:2017 in Quebec]] [[Category:2017 in Rhode Island]] [[Category:2017 in Virginia]] [[Category:2017 in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:2017 in Vermont]] [[Category:2017 meteorology]] [[Category:Blizzards in Canada]] [[Category:Blizzards in the United States]] [[Category:March 2017 events in North America|Blizzard]] [[Category:Nor'easters]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} '''Moisture sensitivity level''' relates to the packaging and handling precautions for some semiconductors. The MSL is an [[Electronics|electronic]] standard for the time period in which a moisture sensitive device can be exposed to ambient room conditions (30 °C/85%RH at Level 1; 30 °C/60%RH at all other levels).
Increasingly, [[semiconductors]] have been manufactured in smaller sizes. Components such as thin fine-pitch devices and [[ball grid array]]s could be damaged during [[Surface-mount technology|SMT]] reflow when moisture trapped inside the component expands.
The expansion of trapped moisture can result in internal separation ([[delamination]]) of the plastic from the die or lead-frame, wire bond damage, die damage, and internal cracks. Most of this damage is not visible on the component surface. In extreme cases, cracks will extend to the component surface. In the most severe cases, the component will bulge and pop. This is known as the "popcorn" effect.
[[IPC (electronics)|IPC]] (Association Connecting Electronic Industries) created and released IPC-M-109, Moisture-sensitive Component Standards and Guideline Manual (''not active'').
Moisture sensitive devices are packaged in a moisture barrier [[antistatic bag]] with a [[desiccant]] and a moisture indicator card which is sealed.
IPC-M-109 includes seven documents. According to [http://www.jedec.org/sites/default/files/docs/jstd020d-01.pdf]: Moisture/reflow sensitivity classification for plastic Integrated circuit (IC) SMDs, there are eight levels of moisture sensitivity. Components must be mounted and reflowed within the allowable period of time (floor life out of the bag).
* '''MSL 6''' – '''Mandatory Bake before use''' * '''MSL 5A''' – '''24 hours''' * '''MSL 5''' – '''48 hours''' * '''MSL 4''' – '''72 hours''' * '''MSL 3''' – '''168 hours''' * '''MSL 2A''' – '''4 weeks''' * '''MSL 2''' – '''1 year''' * '''MSL 1''' – '''Unlimited'''
== References == IPC/JEDEC J-STD-020E, Moisture/Reflow Sensitivity Classification for Nonhermetic Surface Mount Devices, December 2014.

Giovanny Arroba's TA60 exterior was chosen in late 2000, with a final production freeze in July 2001. The design language of the future truck was previewed by the 2001 Alpha T concept shown at the 2001 [[Detroit Auto Show]], which had previously developed through November 2000. Production began on September 21, 2003 and sales on December 1, 2003.{{cite news|url= http://articles.latimes.com/2003/jun/15/business/fi-nissan15 |title=Along for the Ride |date=June 15, 2003 |first=John |last=O'Dell |newspaper=The Los Angeles Times |accessdate=December 3, 2015}}{{cite web|url= http://www.just-auto.com/analysis/infiniti-goes-big_id86183.aspx |title=Infiniti Goes Big |date=March 23, 2004 |work=Just Auto |accessdate=December 3, 2015}} The Titan used Nissan's new full-size [[Nissan F-Alpha platform|F-Alpha platform]]. This new platform was shared with the [[Nissan Armada]] and [[Infiniti QX56]] [[SUV]]s, with all three manufactured in [[Canton, Mississippi]], [[United States]]. The first generation Titan continued without a major redesign through 2015. ===Specifications=== ====Models and equipment==== All models came standard with a 32-valve, 5.6-liter engine, VK56DE, which generates {{Convert|317|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} ({{convert|305|hp|kW|0|abbr=on|disp=or}} on 2004–2006 models) and {{convert|385|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} of torque. The first generation Titan came equipped with a fully boxed ladder frame and was available in either rear-wheel drive or a shift-on-the-fly four-wheel-drive system coupled with a five-speed RE505A automatic transmission. An automatic brake-limited slip (ABLS) system was available on all Titans. The first generation was available as a King Cab (extended cab) or a crew cab with a full-sized back seat, with no regular cab being offered. The King Cab featured a {{convert|6|ft|7|in|adj=on}} bed, while the crew cab had a {{convert|5|ft|7|in|adj=on}} bed. In 2008, a longer wheelbase model was offered with either an {{convert|8|ft|3|in|adj=on}} bed on the King Cab or a {{convert|7|ft|3|in|adj=on}} bed on the crew cab. There were originally four trim levels available: the S, SV, Pro-4x, SE, and LE. The SE and LE trim was eventually replaced by the luxury SL trim. The S was the base model, the SV a mid-level model with more features, the PRO-4X was the off-road-oriented version, and the top level SL was offered with features like 20-inch alloy wheels as standard equipment. ====Features==== [[File:Nissan Titan King Cab 002.jpg|thumb|left|2004 Nissan Titan King Cab]] [[File:2008 Nissan Titan long bed.jpg|thumb|left|2008 Nissan Titan crew cab long bed]] Features available on the first generation included: * Bluetooth hands-free * Navigation system * [[DVD player]] with screen * Side [[airbag]]s * Pro-4X off-road package * Traction control * Sunroof * Big tow package with transmission temperature gauge and telescoping mirrors * [[XM Satellite Radio]] * Leather split power bench seat * Utili-Track bed rail system * Lockable bedside storage box * Leather-appointed heated captains chairs with console automatic shifter * Rear sonar warning system * Automatic windows down with key fob * Power adjustable pedals * Flexible fuel vehicle * 168-degree king cab rear door openings ====Safety==== The first generation Titan carried a five-star rating from the [[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration]] for driver frontal crash, and a four-star rating for passenger frontal crash. * Vehicle dynamic control standard on 2010 models and up * Side and front airbags standard on 2010 models and up * Antilock brakes standard on all {{clear}} == Second generation (2016–present) == {{Infobox automobile | name = Nissan Titan (H61) | image = Nissan Titan V8 P4220668.jpg | interioralt = | production = November 20, 2015 – present (Titan XD) | model_years = 2016–present | assembly = Canton, Mississippi, U.S. | designer = Randy Rodriguez{{cite web|url=https://electrek.co/2016/09/05/tesla-hires-designer-randy-rodriguez-nissan-370z-icon-a5-aircraft-nissan-titan/|title=Tesla hires top designer Randy Rodriguez, man behind: Nissan 370Z, Titan and ICON A5 aircraft|work=Electrek|accessdate=5 September 2016}} (exterior: 2012)

6-speed automatic (diesel) | wheelbase = | length = | width = | height = | weight = }} The second-generation Titan was to be a lightly reskinned, rebadged version of the Dodge Ram, but those plans fell through with the 2008 worldwide financial crisis.http://jalopnik.com/379676/chrysler-to-produce-full-size-trucks-for-nissan-what-the-truckhttp://www.caranddriver.com/news/next-gen-nissan-titan-to-get-most-dodge-ram-attributes-car-newshttp://news.pickuptrucks.com/2009/02/nissan-and-chrysler-halt-rambased-titan-effort.html Nissan unveiled the second generation Titan at the 2015 [[North American International Auto Show]].{{cite web |url=http://www.slashgear.com/nissan-unveils-new-titan-xd-truck-in-detroit-with-cummins-diesel-option-13364175/ |title=Nissan unveils new Titan XD truck in Detroit with V8 Cummins diesel option |work=SlashGear |author=McGlaun, Shane |date=January 13, 2015 |accessdate=July 6, 2015}} The second generation Titan was designed in California, engineered in Michigan, tested in Arizona, and is assembled in Mississippi. The V8 Cummins is built in Indiana and Tennessee. [[Cummins]] has partnered with Nissan and has announced that the next generation Titan will offer a {{convert|310|hp|adj=on}} Cummins 5.0-liter turbo diesel V8 (after plans with Dodge fell through) that produces almost {{convert|555|lbft}} of torque. The engine is referred to as the ISV. The engine will be built in [[Columbus, Indiana]], and have a different version of the engine for commercial trucks.{{cite web|url=http://cumminsengines.com/cummins-5L-V8-turbo-diesel|title=Cummins 5.0 Turbo V8|accessdate=21 August 2013}} The 5.6-liter gasoline engine will remain standard. http://www.nissanusa.com/trucks/titan/versions-specs?tool=model.top_nav.section.link Additionally, the gasoline engine has increased in power compared to the previous model, producing {{Convert|390|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|394|lbft|Nm|0}} of torque mated to a 7-speed [[Automatic transmission|automatic]]. The 2nd-generation Titan is available in two forms, regular and XD, with the XD having been released for sale first. The XD version is built on a heavy-duty frame based on Nissan's commercial vehicle line and includes the Cummins diesel engine as an option. The platform is shared with the [[Nissan NV (North America)|Nissan NV]]. '''PAMELA''' ('''Payload for Antimatter Matter Exploration and Light-nuclei Astrophysics''') was a [[cosmic ray]] research module attached to an Earth orbiting satellite. ''PAMELA'' was launched on 15 June 2006 and was the first [[satellite]]-based experiment dedicated to the detection of [[cosmic rays]], with a particular focus on their [[antimatter]] component, in the form of [[positron]]s and [[antiproton]]s. Other objectives included long-term monitoring of the solar modulation of cosmic rays, measurements of energetic particles from the [[Sun]], high-energy particles in Earth's [[magnetosphere]] and [[gas giant|Jovian]] electrons. It was also hoped that it may detect evidence of [[dark matter]] annihilation.<ref name="wizardpamela">{{cite web | url=http://wizard.roma2.infn.it/pamela/ | title=The Space Mission PAMELA | editor=Vincenzo Buttaro | accessdate=4 September 2009}}</ref> PAMELA operations were terminated in 2016,<ref name="summary">{{Cite journal| title=Ten Years of PAMELA in Space | journal=Rivista del Nuovo Cimento| volume=10| issue=2017| pages=473–522| arxiv=1801.10310 |last1 = Adriani|first1 = O | display-authors=etal |collaboration=PAMELA Collaboration| year=2018| doi=10.1393/ncr/i2017-10140-x}}</ref> as were the operations of the host-satellite [[Resurs-DK1]].
==Development and launch== ''PAMELA'' was the largest device up to the time built by the Wizard collaboration, which includes Russia, Italy, Germany and Sweden and has been involved in many satellite and balloon-based cosmic ray experiments such as [[Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope|Fermi-GLAST]]. The 470 kg, US$32 million (EU€24.8 million, UK£16.8 million) instrument was originally projected to have a three-year mission. However, this durable module remained operational and made significant scientific contributions until 2016.
''PAMELA'' is mounted on the upward-facing side of the [[Resurs-DK1]] Russian satellite.<ref name="wizardpamela"/> It was launched by a [[Soyuz (rocket)|Soyuz]] rocket from [[Baikonur Cosmodrome]] on 15 June 2006. ''PAMELA'' has been put in a polar elliptical orbit at an altitude between 350 and 610 km, with an inclination of 70°.
==Design== The apparatus is 1.3 m high, has a total mass of 470 kg and a power consumption of 335 W. The instrument is built around a permanent magnet spectrometer with a silicon microstrip tracker that provides rigidity and dE/dx information. At its bottom is a silicon-tungsten imaging calorimeter, a neutron detector and a shower tail scintillator to perform lepton/hadron discrimination. A Time of Flight (ToF), made of three layers of plastic scintillators, is used to measure the velocity and charge of the particle. An anticounter system made of scintillators surrounding the apparatus is used to reject false triggers and albedo particles during off-line analysis.<ref>{{Cite journal|arxiv=0708.1808|last1=Casolino|first1=M| display-authors=etal|title=Launch of the Space experiment PAMELA|journal=Advances in Space Research|volume=42|issue=3|pages=455–466|year=2007|doi=10.1016/j.asr.2007.07.023|bibcode=2008AdSpR..42..455C}}</ref>
{| class=wikitable |+ Sensitivity<ref name="wizardpamela"/> |- !Particle !Energy Range |- |Antiproton flux |80 MeV – 190 GeV |- |Positron flux |50 MeV – 270 GeV |- |Electron flux |up to 400 GeV |- |Proton flux |up to 700 GeV |- |Electron/positron flux |up to 2 TeV |- |Light nuclei (up to Z=6) |up to 200 GeV/n |- |Light isotopes (D, 3He) |up to 1 GeV/n |- |Antinuclei search |sensitivity better than 10<sup>−7</sup> antiHe/He |}
==Results== Preliminary data (released August 2008, ICHEP Philadelphia) indicate an excess of positrons in the range 10–60 GeV. This is thought to be a possible sign of [[dark matter]] annihilation:<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Brumfiel|first1=Geoff|title=Physicists await dark-matter confirmation|journal=Nature|date=14 August 2008|volume=454|issue=7206|pages=808–809|doi=10.1038/454808b}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|arxiv=0810.5344|last1=Cholis|first1=Ilias|title=The PAMELA Positron Excess from Annihilations into a Light Boson|journal=Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics|volume=2009|issue=12|pages=007|last2=Finkbeiner|first2=Douglas P|last3=Goodenough|first3=Lisa|last4=Weiner|first4=Neal|year=2008|doi=10.1088/1475-7516/2009/12/007|bibcode=2009JCAP...12..007C}}</ref> hypothetical [[WIMPs]] colliding with and annihilating each other to form gamma rays, matter and antimatter particles. Another explanation considered for the indication mentioned above is the production of electron-positron pairs on pulsars with subsequent acceleration in the vicinity of the pulsar.
The first two years of data were released in October 2008 in three publications.<ref>{{Cite journal|arxiv=0810.4980|last1=Casolino|first1=M| display-authors=etal|title=Two years of flight of the Pamela experiment: Results and perspectives|journal=Journal of the Physical Society of Japan|volume=78|pages=35|year=2008|doi=10.1143/JPSJS.78SA.35|bibcode=2009JPSJ...78S..35C}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|arxiv=0810.4995|last1=Adriani|first1=O|title=Observation of an anomalous positron abundance in the cosmic radiation|journal=Nature|volume=458|issue=7238|pages=607–609| display-authors=etal|year=2008|doi=10.1038/nature07942|bibcode=2009Natur.458..607A}}</ref> The positron excess was confirmed and found to persist up to 90 GeV. Surprisingly, no excess of antiprotons was found. This is inconsistent with predictions from most models of dark matter sources, in which the positron and antiproton excesses are correlated.
A paper, published on 15 July 2011, confirmed earlier speculation that the [[Van Allen belt]] could confine a significant flux of [[antiproton]]s produced by the interaction of the Earth's upper atmosphere with [[cosmic ray]]s.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1088/2041-8205/737/2/L29 | title = The Discovery of Geomagnetically Trapped Cosmic-Ray Antiprotons | year = 2011 | last1 = Adriani | first1 = O. | display-authors=etal | journal = The Astrophysical Journal Letters | volume = 737 | issue = 2 | pages = L29 | bibcode = 2011ApJ...737L..29A | arxiv=1107.4882 }}</ref> The energy of the antiprotons has been measured in the range of 60–750 MeV. Cosmic rays collide with atoms in the upper atmosphere creating [[antineutron]]s, which in turn decay to produce the antiprotons. They were discovered in a part of the Van Allen belt closest to Earth.<ref>{{cite news | last = Than | first = Ker | title = Antimatter Found Orbiting Earth—A First | url = http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2011/08/110810-antimatter-belt-earth-trapped-pamela-space-science/ | publisher=[[National Geographic Society]] | date = 10 August 2011 | accessdate =12 August 2011}}</ref> When an antiproton interacts with a normal particle, both are annihilated. Data from PAMELA indicated that these [[annihilation]] events occurred a thousand times more often than would be expected in the absence of [[antimatter]]. The data that contained evidence of antimatter were gathered between July 2006 and December 2008.<ref>{{cite news | last = Cowen | first = Ron | title = Antimatter Belt Found Circling Earth | url = http://news.sciencemag.org/sciencenow/2011/08/antimatter-belt-found-circling-e.html | work = [[Science (magazine)|Science]] | date = 9 August 2011 | accessdate = 12 August 2011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111024152418/http://news.sciencemag.org/sciencenow/2011/08/antimatter-belt-found-circling-e.html | archivedate = 24 October 2011 | df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = Chung | first = Emily | title = Antimatter belt surrounds Earth | url = http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/story/2011/08/08/science-antimatter-belt.html | publisher=[[CBC News]] | date = 8 August 2011 | accessdate =12 August 2011}}</ref>
Boron and carbon flux measurements were published in July 2014,<ref>{{Cite journal |title = MEASUREMENT OF BORON AND CARBON FLUXES IN COSMIC RAYS WITH THE PAMELA EXPERIMENT |date = July 31, 2014|journal = Astrophysical Journal|volume = 791|issue = 2|pages = 93 |doi = 10.1088/0004-637X/791/2/93|pmid = |arxiv = 1407.1657 |bibcode = 2014ApJ...791...93A |last1 = Adriani|first1 = O| display-authors=etal}}</ref> important to explaining trends in cosmic ray positron fraction.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Constraining the origin of the rising cosmic ray positron fraction with the boron-to-carbon ratio|last = |first = |date = Feb 24, 2014|journal = Phys Rev D|volume = 89|issue = 4|pages = 043013|accessdate = |doi = 10.1103/PhysRevD.89.043013|pmid = |arxiv = 1312.2952 |bibcode = 2014PhRvD..89d3013C |last1 = Cholis|first1 = Ilias|last2 = Hooper|first2 = Dan}}</ref>
The summary document of the operations of PAMELA was published in 2017.<ref name="summary"/>
==Sources of error==
Between 1 and 100 GeV, ''PAMELA'' is exposed to one hundred times as many electrons as antiprotons. At 1 GeV there are one thousand times as many protons as positrons and at 100 GeV ten thousand times as many. Therefore, to correctly determine the antimatter abundances, it is critical that PAMELA is able to reject the matter background. The PAMELA collaboration claimed in [http://www.slac.stanford.edu/spires/find/hep/www?j=APHYE,26,111 The electron hadron separation performance of the PAMELA electromagnetic calorimeter]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} that less than one proton in 100,000 is able to pass the [[calorimeter]] selection and be misidentified as a positron when the energy is less than 200 GeV.
The ratio of matter to antimatter in cosmic rays of energy less than 10 GeV that reach PAMELA from outside the [[solar system]] depends on solar activity and in particular on the point in the 11 year [[solar cycle]]. The ''PAMELA'' team has invoked this effect to explain the discrepancy between their low energy results and those obtained by ''[http://ida1.physik.uni-siegen.de/caprice.html CAPRICE]'', ''[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1998APS..4CF..B201N HEAT]'' and ''[[Alpha Magnetic Spectrometer|AMS-01]]'', which were collected during that half of the cycle when the [[solar magnetic field]] had the opposite polarity. It is important to note that these results are consistent with the series of positron / electron measurements obtain by ''[http://www.bartol.udel.edu/~balloon/ AESOP]'', which has spanned coverage over both polarities. Also the ''PAMELA'' experiment has contradicted an earlier claim by the ''HEAT'' experiment of anomalous positrons in the 6 GeV to 10 GeV range.
==See also== * [[Alpha Magnetic Spectrometer|AMS-02]] is a high energy physics experiment mounted to the exterior of the [[International Space Station]] featured advanced particle identification and large acceptance of 0.3m2sr. AMS-02 in the operation since May 2011. More than 100 billion charged cosmic ray events were recorded by AMS so far.

[[Royal Medal]] {{small|(1886)}} | religion = }} [[File:17 Drummond Place, Edinburgh.jpg|thumb|Tait's house at 17 Drummond Place, Edinburgh]] '''Peter Guthrie Tait''' [[FRSE]] (28 April 1831 – 4 July 1901) was a Scottish [[Mathematical physics|mathematical physicist]] and early pioneer in [[thermodynamics]]. He is best known for the mathematical physics textbook ''[[Treatise on Natural Philosophy]]'', which he co-wrote with [[William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin|Kelvin]], and his early investigations into [[knot theory]], His work on knot theory contributed to the eventual formation of [[topology]] as a mathematical discipline. His name is known in [[graph theory]] mainly for [[Tait's conjecture]]. == Early life == Tait was born in [[Dalkeith]] on 28 April 1831 the only son of Mary Ronaldson and John Tait, secretary to the [[Walter Montagu Douglas Scott, 5th Duke of Buccleuch|5th Duke of Buccleuch]].{{Citation|title=Tait, Peter Guthrie (1831–1901), physicist and mathematician {{!}} Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/36407|work=The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|publisher=Oxford University Press|language=en|doi=10.1093/ref:odnb/36407|access-date=2018-07-20}} He was educated at Dalkeith Grammar School then [[Edinburgh Academy]]. He then studied Maths and Physics at the [[University of Edinburgh]], and then went to [[Peterhouse, Cambridge]], graduating as [[senior wrangler]] and first [[Smith's prize]]man in 1852.{{acad|id=TT848PG|name=Tait, Peter Guthrie}} As a fellow and lecturer of his college he remained at the University for a further two years, before leaving to take up the professorship of mathematics at [[Queen's College, Belfast]]. There he made the acquaintance of [[Thomas Andrews (scientist)|Thomas Andrews]], whom he joined in researches on the density of [[ozone]] and the action of the electric discharge on [[oxygen]] and other gases, and by whom he was introduced to Sir [[William Rowan Hamilton]] and [[quaternion]]s. == Middle years == [[File:Peter Guthrie Tait.jpg|thumb|left|180px|Peter Guthrie Tait]] In 1860, Tait succeeded his old master, [[James David Forbes|James D. Forbes]], as professor of [[natural philosophy]] at the University of Edinburgh, and occupied the Chair until shortly before his death. The first scientific paper under Tait's name only was published in 1860. His earliest work dealt mainly with mathematical subjects, and especially with [[Quaternion|quaternions]], of which he was the leading exponent after their originator, [[William Rowan Hamilton]]. He was the author of two text-books on them—one an ''Elementary Treatise on Quaternions'' (1867), written with the advice of Hamilton, though not published till after his death, and the other an ''Introduction to Quaternions'' (1873), in which he was aided by [[Philip Kelland]] (1808–1879), one of his teachers at the University of Edinburgh. Quaternions was also one of the themes of his address as president of the mathematical section of the [[British Association for the Advancement of Science]] in 1871. He also produced original work in mathematical and experimental physics. In 1864, he published a short paper on [[thermodynamics]], and from that time his contributions to that and kindred departments of science became frequent and important. In 1871, he emphasised the significance and future importance of the ''principle of the dissipation of energy'' ([[second law of thermodynamics]]). In 1873 he took [[thermoelectricity]] for the subject of his discourse as [[Rede lecturer]] at [[university of Cambridge|Cambridge]], and in the same year he presented the first sketch of his well-known thermoelectric diagram before the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]]. Two years later, researches on "Charcoal Vacua" with [[James Dewar]] led him to see the true dynamical explanation of the [[Crookes radiometer]] in the large [[mean free path]] of the [[molecule]] of the highly rarefied air. From 1879 to 1888, he engaged in difficult experimental investigations. These began with an inquiry into what corrections were required for thermometers operating at great pressure. This was for the benefit of thermometers employed by the [[Challenger expedition|''Challenger'' expedition]] for observing deep-sea temperatures, and were extended to include the compressibility of water, glass, and [[mercury (element)|mercury]]. This work led to the first formulation of the [[Tait equation]], which is widely used to fit liquid density to pressure. Between 1886 and 1892 he published a series of papers on the foundations of the [[kinetic theory of gases]], the fourth of which contained what was, according to [[Lord Kelvin]], the first proof ever given of the [[John James Waterston|Waterston]]-[[James Clerk Maxwell|Maxwell]] [[theorem]] ([[equipartition theorem]]) of the average equal partition of energy in a mixture of two gases. About the same time he carried out investigations into impact and its duration. Many other inquiries conducted by him might be mentioned, and some idea may be gained of his scientific activity from the fact that a selection only from his papers, published by the [[Cambridge University Press]], fills three large volumes. This mass of work was done in the time he could spare from his professorial teaching in the university. For example, in 1880 he worked on the [[Four color theorem]] and proved that it was true if and only if no [[snark (graph theory)|snarks]] were planar. == Later years == [[File:Memorial plaque to Peter Guthrie Tait, St Johns Episcopal Church, Edinburgh.JPG|300px|thumb|Memorial plaque to Peter Guthrie Tait, St Johns Episcopal Church, Edinburgh]] [[File:The grave of Peter Guthrie Tait, St Johns Episcopal Church, Princes St, Edinburgh.jpg|thumb|300px|The grave of Peter Guthrie Tait, St Johns Episcopal Church, Princes St, Edinburgh]] In addition, he was the author of a number of books and articles. Of the former, the first, published in 1856, was on the dynamics of a particle; and afterwards there followed a number of concise treatises on [[thermodynamics]], heat, light, properties of matter and dynamics, together with an admirably lucid volume of popular lectures on Recent Advances in Physical Science. With Lord Kelvin, he collaborated in writing the well-known ''[[Treatise on Natural Philosophy]]''. "Thomson and Tait," as it is familiarly called (" T and T' " was the authors' own formula), was planned soon after Lord Kelvin became acquainted with Tait, on the latter's appointment to his professorship in Edinburgh, and it was intended to be an all-comprehensive treatise on physical science, the foundations being laid in [[kinematics]] and [[dynamics (mechanics)|dynamics]], and the structure completed with the properties of [[matter]], heat, light, electricity and [[magnetism]]. But the literary partnership ceased in about eighteen years, when only the first portion of the plan had been completed, because each of the members felt he could work to better advantage separately than jointly. The friendship, however, endured for the remaining twenty-three years of Tait's life. Tait collaborated with [[Balfour Stewart]] in the ''Unseen Universe'', which was followed by ''Paradoxical Philosophy''. It was in his 1875 review of ''The Unseen Universe'', that William James first put forth his [[Will to Believe Doctrine]]. Tait's articles include those he wrote for the ninth edition of the ''[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]'' on light, mechanics, quaternions, radiation, and thermodynamics, and the biographical notices of Hamilton and James Clerk Maxwell. He died in Edinburgh on 4 July 1901. He is buried in the second terrace down from [[Princes Street]] in the burial ground of [[St John's Episcopal Church, Edinburgh]]. ==Topology== The [[Tait conjectures]] are three conjectures made by Tait in his study of knots. The Tait conjectures involve concepts in [[knot theory]] such as [[alternating knot]]s, [[chirality]], and [[writhe]]. All of the Tait conjectures have been solved, the most recent being the Flyping conjecture, proved my [[Morwen Thistlethwaite]] and [[William Menasco]] in 1991. ==Publications== [[File:Postcard-from-Maxwell-to-Tait.jpg|thumb|200px|A postcard from [[James Clerk Maxwell]] to Tait.]] * ''Dynamics of a Particle'' (1856) * ''Treatise on Natural Philosophy'' (1867); [https://archive.org/details/treatisnatphil01kelvrich v. 1] and [https://archive.org/details/treatisnatphil02kelvrich v. 2] (PDF/DjVu at the [[Internet Archive]]). * ''An elementary treatise on quaternions'' (1867); [https://archive.org/details/anelementarytre03taitgoog PDF/DjVu] Copy of the 1st ed. at the [[Internet Archive]] and [https://archive.org/details/117770257 PDF/DjVu] Copy of the 3rd ed. at the [[Internet Archive]]. * ''Elements of Natural Philosophy'' (1872); [https://archive.org/details/elementsnatural04taitgoog] (PDF/DjVu at the [[Internet Archive]]). A "non-mathematical portion of ''Treatise on Natural Philosophy''". * ''Sketch of Thermodynamics'' (1877); [https://archive.org/details/sketchofthermody00taituoft PDF/DjVu] Copy at the [[Internet Archive]]. * ''Recent Advances in Physical Science'' (1876); [https://archive.org/details/lecturesonrecent00taitrich PDF/DjVu] Copy at the [[Internet Archive]]. * ''Heat'' (1884); [https://archive.org/details/heatpeter00taitrich PDF/DjVu] Copy at the [[Internet Archive]]. * ''Light'' (1884); [https://archive.org/details/lighttaitpetergu00taitrich PDF/DjVu] Copy at the [[Internet Archive]]. * ''Properties of Matter'' (1885); [https://archive.org/details/propertiesofmatt00taitrich PDF/DjVu] Copy at the [[Internet Archive]]. * ''Dynamics'' (1895); [https://archive.org/details/treatiseondynami00taituoft PDF/DjVu] Copy at the [[Internet Archive]]. * ''The Unseen Universe'' (1875; new edition, 1901) * ''Scientific papers'' vol. 1 (1898–1900) [https://archive.org/details/scientificpapers01taituoft PDF/DjVu] Copy at the [[Internet Archive]]. * ''Scientific papers'' vol. 2 (1898–1900) [https://archive.org/details/scientificpapers02taituoft PDF/DjVu] Copy at the [[Internet Archive]]. == Private life == Tait was married to Margaret Archer Porter (1839-1926), the sister of (1) [[William Archer Porter]], a [[lawyer]] and [[educationist]] who served as the Principal of [[Government Arts College, Kumbakonam]] and tutor and secretary to the Maharaja of [[Mysore kingdom|Mysore]], (2) [[James Porter (Master of Peterhouse, Cambridge)]] and (3) Jane Bailie Porter, who married [[Alexander Crum Brown]], the Scottish organic chemist. Tait was an enthusiastic golfer and, of his seven children, two, [[Frederick Guthrie Tait]] (1870–1900) and [[John Guthrie Tait]] (1861–1945) went on to become gifted amateur golf champions. He was an all-round sportsman and represented Scotland at international level in [[rugby union]]. Tait himself had, in 1891, invoked the [[Magnus effect]] to explain the influence of [[rotation|spin]] on the flight of a [[golf ball]]. His daughter Edith Tait was married to Rev. [[Harry Reid (bishop)|Harry Reid]], who later became [[Bishop of Edinburgh]]. His son [[William Archer Porter Tait]] was a [[civil engineer]]. ==Artistic recognition== Tait was a lifelong friend of [[James Clerk Maxwell]], and a portrait of Tait by [[Harrington Mann]] is held in the [[James Clerk Maxwell Foundation]] museum in Edinburgh.http://www.clerkmaxwellfoundation.org/html/birthplace.html == References == {{reflist}} == External links == {{wikiquote}} {{Wikisource author}} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Peter Tait |birth=1831 |death=1901}} *{{MacTutor Biography|id=Tait|title=Peter Guthrie Tait}} *Pritchard, Chris. "[http://www.maths.ed.ac.uk/~aar/knots/taitbib.htm Provisional Bibliography of Peter Guthrie Tait]". British Society for the History of Mathematics. *An Elementary Treatise on Quaternions, 1890, Cambridge University Press. [https://archive.org/details/117770257 Scanned PDF], [http://www.zipcon.net/~swhite/docs/math/quaternions/ElemTreatQuater/ HTML version (in progress)] *{{EB1911 |wstitle=Tait, Peter Guthrie |volume=26 |pages=364–365}} *"[http://www.maths.ed.ac.uk/~aar/knots Knot Theory]" Website of Andrew Ranicki in Edinburgh. {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tait, Peter Guthrie}} [[Category:Scottish physicists]] [[Category:Scottish mathematicians]] [[Category:Scottish Episcopalians]] [[Category:Thermodynamicists]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Alumni of Peterhouse, Cambridge]] [[Category:Fellows of Peterhouse, Cambridge]] [[Category:People educated at Edinburgh Academy]] [[Category:1831 births]] [[Category:1901 deaths]] [[Category:Royal Medal winners]] [[Category:Senior Wranglers]] [[Category:People from Dalkeith]] [[Category:Mathematical physicists]] [[Category:Academics of Queen's University Belfast]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Edinburgh]] [[Category:19th-century British mathematicians]] [[Category:20th-century British mathematicians]]

The '''polyiodides''' are a class of [[polyhalogen anions]] composed entirely of [[iodine]] atoms. The most common and simplest member is the [[triiodide]] ion, {{chem|I|3|−}}. Other known, larger polyiodides include [I<sub>4</sub>]<sup>2−</sup>, [I<sub>5</sub>]<sup>−</sup>, [I<sub>7</sub>]<sup>−</sup>, [I<sub>8</sub>]<sup>2−</sup>, [I<sub>9</sub>]<sup>−</sup>, [I<sub>10</sub>]<sup>2−</sup>, [I<sub>10</sub>]<sup>4−</sup>, [I<sub>11</sub>]<sup>3−</sup>, [I<sub>12</sub>]<sup>2−</sup>, [I<sub>13</sub>]<sup>3−</sup>, [I<sub>16</sub>]<sup>2−</sup>, [I<sub>22</sub>]<sup>4−</sup>, [I<sub>26</sub>]<sup>3−</sup>, [I<sub>26</sub>]<sup>4−</sup>, [I<sub>28</sub>]<sup>4−</sup> and [I<sub>29</sub>]<sup>3−</sup>.<ref name="InorgChem">{{cite book | title = Inorganic Chemistry | edition = 3rd | chapter = Chapter 17: The group 17 elements | first1 = Catherine E. | last1 = Housecroft | first2 = Alan G. | last2 = Sharpe | publisher = Pearson | year = 2008 | isbn = 978-0-13-175553-6 | page = 547 }}</ref>
==Preparation==
The polyiodides can be made by addition of stoichiometric amounts of I<sub>2</sub> to solutions containing I<sup>−</sup> and {{chem|I|3|−}}, with the presence of large [[cation|counter-cations]] to stabilize them. For example, KI<sub>3</sub>·H<sub>2</sub>O can be crystallized from a saturated solution of [[potassium iodide|KI]] when a stoichiometric amount of I<sub>2</sub> is added and cooled.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|title=Potassium triiodide|encyclopedia=Handbook of Preparative Inorganic Chemistry|edition=2nd|editor-first=G.|editor-last=Brauer|publisher=Academic Press|date=1963|location=New York|volume=1|page=294}}</ref>
==Structure==
[[File:Solid state structure of the (I11)3- ion in (((16)aneS4)PdIPd((16)aneS4))(I11).png|right|thumb|300px|The 14-membered ring array of iodine atoms in [([16]aneS<sub>4</sub>)PdIPd([16]aneS<sub>4</sub>)][I<sub>11</sub>]]]
[[File:Solid state structure of (I26)4- in (DMFc)4(I26).png|right|thumb|300px|The primitive cubic lattice of iodide ions bridge by I<sub>2</sub> molecules, present in [Cp*<sub>2</sub>Fe]<sub>4</sub>[I<sub>26</sub>]]]
Polyiodides are characterized by their highly complex and variable structures, and can be considered as associations of I<sub>2</sub>, I<sup>−</sup>, and {{chem|I|3|−}} units. Discrete polyiodides are usually [[linear molecular geometry|linear]], reflecting the origin of the ion. The more complex two- or three-dimensional network structures of chains and cages are formed as the ions interact with each other, with their shapes depending on their associated [[cation]]s quite strongly.
